author: Emma Munbodh
title: Last chance to cancel Sky penalty-free as firm hikes line rental for millions - or use it to bag a massive discount
text:
If you're a Sky customer, act now (Photo: Alamy/Getty) Share Get money updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Sky customers with a phone or broadband package are to see their bills rise on 1 March, in a move that will affect millions of households. 
The firm announced the news last month, with the first wave of announcement letters and emails sent out to customers on 25 January. Sky says all subscribers will be notified by 25 February 2017 at the latest. 
Line rental is to increase by an extra £19.08 a year - that's an extra £1.49 a month for bill-payers. Read More 
If you've a phone line through Sky or you're a broadband customer, it is likely you'll be affected - however the firm warned those with a TV bundle deal may also be hit. poll loading Does Sky offer good value for money? 3000+ VOTES SO FAR YES NO 
Sky said some customers, who are either on "legacy products", or who had previously been benefiting from a lower price, will also see their bills "brought into line with current pricing". 
The company told Mirror Money the changes "reflect its ongoing investment in on screen line up, technology and customer service". 
A Sky spokesperson said: "The changes we have made to our line rental pricing reflect not only the cost of the physical line to the customers’ door, but also the continued investment in our network, and in delivering the best possible service to customers." 30 days to cancel your plan or bag a better deal If you're not happy - you have 30-days to do something about it (Photo: Getty) 
Ofcom guidelines clearly state that customers have the right to cancel their plan, penalty-free, if a provider hikes prices mid-contract - unless it was in your contract before you signed up. Read More The simple change to your broadband that could save you £105 a year 
To take advantage of this, you'll have to call up within 30-days of receiving confirmation of the price change. 
More importantly, if you were in the first batch of notified customers - you're time is running out - so act now. 
How to cancel 
You'll need your price rise letter/email to hand - make sure you're calling within the 30 day period. 
Get in touch with Sky with your account details ready. You can call its Customer Services team on 0330 041 3130. Alternatively, choose another option from its 'contact us' section online . 
Know your stuff: Ofcom's guidelines for reference: 
An Ofcom spokesperson told Mirror Money: "Ofcom’s rules clearly state that, should a provider introduce increases to the monthly subscription price beyond that agreed by the customer at point of sale, then they must allow that customer to exit their contract without penalty. Read More 
"As a result, customers would be free to take advantage of competition in the market and choose an alternative service that best meets their needs and budget, should they wish to." Alternatively, try and haggle a better deal Don't be afraid to tell your provider you're not happy (Photo: Getty) 
According to consumer website Which? , on average, 81% of Sky customers who haggle get money off. An investigation found that 58% were offered a discount on their bill for a fixed period. 
With your price plan about to rise, now may be a good time to make this call, as not only could you escape the hike entirely, you could end up hundreds of pounds better off. 
Which? says these are the questions to ask when haggling for a better deal. Of course, it also helps to reinforce that you're a 'loyal' customer. 
Hi, I’m not sure I’m getting the best deal available and I’m thinking of cancelling. 
I think I’m paying too much and that newer customers are being offered better deals and better equipment like routers and TV boxes, and I think I’m missing out on these offers. 
If you don’t give me a better deal I’ll have to leave – I’ve seen a better deal from [company name and details]. 
If you succeed, it's likely the company will try and tie you into a new contract - be aware of this before the letter comes through your postbox. "How I saved £100 on my Sky bill" One step ahead: Matt says you can play the firms at their own game 
Worried customer Matt Challis got in touch with Sky after learning that his bills were due to go up , just months after the firm revised its broadband plans. 
"I had planned to call Sky up to discuss my bills the first time they put prices up last year, but other things got in the way and I never got round to it," Matt told Mirror Money. 
"When they told me that part of my bill was going up again it reminded me to act. And seeing as this was on top of the last increase it made it more of a priority. 
"I've been a customer for around two or three years - so I thought, it's definitely worth a try! 
"The customer service was really good. I got through to the department that discussed contracts - it wasn't directly the cancellations team. Read More
